pull_commit_message:
update socket.io

this comes with a few breaking changes to the api. The two that impact corsica both are around initialization.  This patch accommodates these changes by aggregating socket.io config values and initializing in one step instead of iteratively changing config params ahead of starting the server.

pullsbody:
Corsica client makes an optimistic attempt to initiate fullscreen without a user action. In Firefox this creates an apparently uncatchable TypeError. I attempted locally to capture it from the rejected promise or in a larger `try-catch` block but neither worked. This is unlike [the TypeError that can be thrown if the user is prompted and rejects fullscreen](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/requestFullScreen#Exceptions).

This fix adds a note to the console logs before the attempt is made. It also adds a few lines to the README to explain different ways of launching in a kiosk mode for managed deployments.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!
pull_commit_message:
warn about fullscreen in console

Corsica client makes an optimistic attempt to initiate fullscreen without a user action. In Firefox this creates an apparently uncatchable TypeError. This fix adds a note to the console logs before the attempt is made. It also adds a few lines to the README to explain different ways of launching in a kiosk mode for managed deployments.

pullsbody:
Modified app.js  to support admin commands in the querystring:

?default=tagname  - subscribes the client to “tagname” instead of
“default”

?name=foo - change the name of the client to “foo”

?subscribe=tagname1, tagname2….  - Subscribes the client to a list of
one or tags.

?unsubscribe=tagname1, tagname2… - Unsubscribes the client to a list of
one or more tags.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!

pullsbody:
☝️ Greenkeeper’s [updated Terms of Service](https://mailchi.mp/ebfddc9880a9/were-updating-our-terms-of-service) will come into effect on April 6th, 2018.

Let’s get started with automated dependency management for corsica :muscle:



This pull request **updates all your dependencies to their latest version**. Having them all up to date really is the best starting point for keeping up with new releases. Greenkeeper will look out for further dependency updates and make sure to handle them in isolation and in real-time, but only after **you merge this pull request**.

**Important: Greenkeeper will only start watching this repository’s dependency updates after you merge this initial pull request**.



---
<details>
<summary>💥 Tests on this branch are failing. Here’s how to proceed.</summary>

To solve the issue, first find out which of the dependency’s updates is causing the problem. Then fix your code to accomodate the changes in the updated dependency. [next-update](https://www.npmjs.com/package/next-update) is a really handy tool to help you with this.

Then push your changes to this branch and merge it.
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏷 How to check the status of this repository</summary>

Greenkeeper adds a badge to your README which indicates the status of this repository.

This is what your badge looks like right now :point_right:  ![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/mozilla/corsica.svg)
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏗 How to configure Travis CI</summary>

Greenkeeper has added a rule to your `.travis.yml` that whitelists Greenkeeper branches, which are created when your dependencies are updated. Travis CI will run your tests on these branches automatically to see if they still pass.

No additional setup is required 😊

</details>
<details>
<summary>🙈 How to ignore certain dependencies</summary>

You may have good reasons for not wanting to update to a certain dependency right now. In this case, you can [change the dependency’s version string in the `package.json` file back to whatever you prefer](https://github.com/mozilla/corsica/edit/greenkeeper/initial/package.json).

To make sure Greenkeeper doesn’t nag you again on the next update, add a `greenkeeper.ignore` field to your `package.json`, containing a list of dependencies you don’t want to update.

```js
// package.json
{
  …
  "greenkeeper": {
    "ignore": [
      "package-names",
      "you-want-me-to-ignore"
    ]
  }
}
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>👩‍💻 How to update this pull request</summary>

```bash
  # Change into your repository’s directory
  git fetch
  git checkout greenkeeper/initial
  npm install-test
  # Adapt your code until everything works again
  git commit -m 'chore: adapt code to updated dependencies'
  git push origin greenkeeper/initial
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>✨ How do dependency updates work with Greenkeeper?</summary>

After you merge this pull request, **Greenkeeper will create a new branch whenever a  dependency is updated**, with the new version applied. The branch creation should trigger your testing services and check whether your code still works with the new dependency version. Depending on the the results of these tests Greenkeeper will try to open meaningful and helpful pull requests and issues, so your dependencies remain working and up-to-date.

```diff
-  "underscore": "^1.6.0"
+  "underscore": "^1.7.0"
```

The above example shows an in-range update. `1.7.0` is included in the old `^1.6.0` range, because of the [caret `^` character ](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#ranges).
When the test services report success Greenkeeper will silently delete the branch again, because no action needs to be taken – everything is fine.

However, should the tests fail, Greenkeeper will create an issue to inform you about the problem immediately.

This way, you’ll never be surprised by a dependency breaking your code. As long as everything still works, Greenkeeper will stay out of your way, and as soon as something goes wrong, you’ll be the first to know.

```diff
-  "lodash": "^3.0.0"
+  "lodash": "^4.0.0"
```

In this example, the new version `4.0.0` is _not_ included in the old `^3.0.0` range.
For version updates like these – let’s call them “out of range” updates – you’ll receive a pull request.

This means that **you no longer need to check for new versions manually** – Greenkeeper will keep you up to date automatically.

These pull requests not only serve as reminders to update: If you have solid tests and good coverage, and the pull requests passes those tests, you can very likely just merge it and release a new version of your software straight away :shipit:

To get a better idea of which ranges apply to which releases, check out the extremely useful [semver calculator](https://semver.npmjs.com/) provided by npm.
</details>
<details>
<summary>FAQ and help</summary>

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html). If those don’t help, you can always [ask the humans behind Greenkeeper](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
</details>

---


Good luck with your project and see you soon :sparkles:

Your [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io) bot :palm_tree:

<summary>🏷 How to check the status of this repository</summary>

Greenkeeper adds a badge to your README which indicates the status of this repository.

This is what your badge looks like right now :point_right:  ![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/mozilla/corsica.svg)
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏗 How to configure Travis CI</summary>

Greenkeeper has added a rule to your `.travis.yml` that whitelists Greenkeeper branches, which are created when your dependencies are updated. Travis CI will run your tests on these branches automatically to see if they still pass.

No additional setup is required 😊

</details>
<details>
<summary>🙈 How to ignore certain dependencies</summary>

You may have good reasons for not wanting to update to a certain dependency right now. In this case, you can [change the dependency’s version string in the `package.json` file back to whatever you prefer](https://github.com/mozilla/corsica/edit/greenkeeper/initial/package.json).

To make sure Greenkeeper doesn’t nag you again on the next update, add a `greenkeeper.ignore` field to your `package.json`, containing a list of dependencies you don’t want to update.

```js
// package.json
{
  …
  "greenkeeper": {
    "ignore": [
      "package-names",
      "you-want-me-to-ignore"
    ]
  }
}
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>👩‍💻 How to update this pull request</summary>

```bash
  # Change into your repository’s directory
  git fetch
  git checkout greenkeeper/initial
  npm install-test
  # Adapt your code until everything works again
  git commit -m 'chore: adapt code to updated dependencies'
  git push origin greenkeeper/initial
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>✨ How do dependency updates work with Greenkeeper?</summary>

After you merge this pull request, **Greenkeeper will create a new branch whenever a  dependency is updated**, with the new version applied. The branch creation should trigger your testing services and check whether your code still works with the new dependency version. Depending on the the results of these tests Greenkeeper will try to open meaningful and helpful pull requests and issues, so your dependencies remain working and up-to-date.

```diff
-  "underscore": "^1.6.0"
+  "underscore": "^1.7.0"
```

The above example shows an in-range update. `1.7.0` is included in the old `^1.6.0` range, because of the [caret `^` character ](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#ranges).
When the test services report success Greenkeeper will silently delete the branch again, because no action needs to be taken – everything is fine.

However, should the tests fail, Greenkeeper will create an issue to inform you about the problem immediately.

This way, you’ll never be surprised by a dependency breaking your code. As long as everything still works, Greenkeeper will stay out of your way, and as soon as something goes wrong, you’ll be the first to know.

```diff
-  "lodash": "^3.0.0"
+  "lodash": "^4.0.0"
```

In this example, the new version `4.0.0` is _not_ included in the old `^3.0.0` range.
For version updates like these – let’s call them “out of range” updates – you’ll receive a pull request.

This means that **you no longer need to check for new versions manually** – Greenkeeper will keep you up to date automatically.

These pull requests not only serve as reminders to update: If you have solid tests and good coverage, and the pull requests passes those tests, you can very likely just merge it and release a new version of your software straight away :shipit:

To get a better idea of which ranges apply to which releases, check out the extremely useful [semver calculator](https://semver.npmjs.com/) provided by npm.
</details>
<details>
<summary>FAQ and help</summary>

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html). If those don’t help, you can always [ask the humans behind Greenkeeper](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
</details>

---


Good luck with your project and see you soon :sparkles:

Your [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io) bot :palm_tree:

pullsbody: fixes issue #29 by changing `toast` to only set a timeout if the timeout is provided and is 0 or greater. `ident` provides an explicit timeout, so that remains unchanged.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!
pull_commit_message:
stay indefinitely when timeout < 0

fixes issue #29 by avoiding setting a timeout when the provided timeout value
is less than 0. ident sets its own timeout value already so no need to modify anything else.

pullsbody:
This stores the Brain state in a JSON file in a semi-human readable format. In particular, it is a JSON object who's values are JSON string encodings of JS objects.

This also keeps everything in memory always, and sync's it back to disk. It's probably fine for us.

This is a change in format from the leveldb backend, and will require manual intervention (or to throw away all the old state). Things stored in state include timer configs, group playlists, and irc configs.

pullsbody:
Some things on our radar involve an admin UI that is smarter than what settings provides us so far. For example, _if_ we implement weights, that UI will need to be different a way I'm not sure can be expressed with just our current settings UI. Group reset is also beyond the settings UI.

This approach might be kind of radical. It lets any plugin register panels on the admin screen, as well as run arbitrary scripts on the admin screen. This is also kind of a sketch of what client side plugins might look like in the future. Oh, and I brought in Nunjucks.
- [x] Draw admin UI as plugin-driven panels.
- [x] Add behavior with plugin-driven admin scripts.
- [ ] Port settings to new system
  - [x] Make settings work for scalar values.
  - [ ] Make settings work for array values. (Currently draws, but does not update).
- [ ] Make the message log a plugin.
- [ ] Make command and control a plugin.
- [ ] Move groups back to the main admin screen?
- [ ] Tweak the UI as needed.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!
pull_commit_message: New admin idea. HTML only, no JS yet.

pullsbody:
1. Move plugin loading into a separate module.
2. Separate loading, sorting, and initializing steps.0
3. Plugins may now be an object with metadata and an `init` method.
4. Plugins state dependencies through requires, before, after, and phase properties.
5. Plugins will be re-ordered at load time to satisfy ordering metadata.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!
pull_commit_message:
First pass at dependency graph.

If a dependency is not fulfilled get angry.

pullsbody:
1. Move plugin loading into a separate module.
2. Separate loading, sorting, and initializing steps.0
3. Plugins may now be an object with metadata and an `init` method.
4. Plugins state dependencies through requires, before, after, and phase properties.
5. Plugins will be re-ordered at load time to satisfy ordering metadata.
pull_repo_desc: Customizable signage powered by the web - empathic screens for the masses!
pull_commit_message:
Reorder plugins to satisfy dependencies.

This uses Topological sort with before, after and phase.

Still gets angry if something is not available.
